p: Typically, migratory distance is calculated as the great-circle distance between breeding and non-breeding range centroids [ 9, 18, 20]. However, this simple calculation obscures the complex variety of between- and within-species migratory movements [ 21]. Migratory connectivity—the extent to which breeding and non-breeding populations of a species remain connected—varies significantly among species [ 22, 23]. The degree to which birds use the same migration route can fluctuate not only among individuals within a population but also between years for individuals [ 24], and between spring and autumn for the same individual [ 25]. If the potential impacts of climate change on migration are to be identified, it is important that this potential variation within species in migration distances is considered.
